# REVIEW APPRAISER'S SCOPE OF WORK, LIMITING CONDITIONS, AND CERTIFICATION 

INTENDED USE: The intended use of this appraisal desk review is to assist the client in determining possible appraisal deficiencies. This review should not be used for loan financing purposes.

INTENDED USERS: The intended user of this appraisal desk review is the lender/client.
DEFINITION OF MARKET VALUE: The most probable price which a property should bring in a competitive and open market under all conditions requisite to a fair sale, the buyer and seller, each acting prudently, knowledgeably and assuming the price is not affected by undue stimulus. Implicit in this definition is the consummation of a sale as of a specified date and the passing of title from seller to buyer under conditions whereby: (1) buyer and seller are typically motivated; (2) both parties are well informed or well advised, and each acting in what he or she considers his or her own best interest; (3) a reasonable time is allowed for exposure in the open market; (4) payment is made in terms of cash in U.S. dollars or in terms of financial arrangements comparable thereto; and (5) the price represents the normal consideration for the property sold unaffected by special or creative financing or sales concessions* granted by anyone associated with the sale.
*Adjustments to the comparables must be made for special or creative financing or sales concessions. No adjustments are necessary for those costs which are normally paid by sellers as a result of tradition or law in a market area; these costs are readily identifiable since the seller pays these costs in virtually all sales transactions. Special or creative financing adjustments can be made to the comparable property by comparisons to financing terms offered by a third party institutional lender that is not already involved with the property or transaction. Any adjustment should not be calculated on a mechanical dollar for dollar cost of the financing or concession but the dollar amount of any adjustment should approximate the market's reaction to the financing or concessions based on the appraiser's judgment.

SCOPE OF WORK: My scope of work included the review of appraisal reports and other documents. This appraisal review is intended to comply with Standards Rule 3 of the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP). Appraisal reports under review, real estate and real property interests appraised, date of reports and effective dates of value estimates, date of review, identity of appraisers, and identity of the internal reviewer are all contained within the internal review report. All known pertinent information was included. The purpose of this review was to assess the reasonableness of the value estimate(s) and determine compliance with USPAP. Appraisal reports subject to review have been read and analyzed to form an opinion as to:
I. Completeness of the report under review within the scope of work applicable in the review assignment;
a. Apparent adequacy, relevance, and appropriateness of data and adjustments; and,
b. Whether the analyses, methods, opinions, and conclusions in the reports under review are appropriate and reasonable. Reasons for any disagreement are contained within this review report.
c. Additional Valuation Reports such as BPDs (Broker Price Opinions), AVMs and various additional valuation products could be included in this review and analysis.

If the scope of this internal appraisal review includes an independent value conclusion, it is developed and reported in compliance with USPAP, SR 3. The purpose of such an internal review appraisal is to estimate market value of the fee simple interest in the subject, and intended to assist the underwriter in determining possible appraisal deficiencies. Service 1st Valuation and Settlement Services Inc. and its direct client is the only intended user. I have extended, by way of Extraordinary Assumption, those portions of the original appraisal that are considered credible and developed in compliance with USPAP Standard I. Portions of the reviewed reports that are not considered credible and developed in compliance with USPAP Standard I are described in this internal appraisal review report. Supplemental review information may include but is not limited to information from public records, multiple listing services, national vendors, real estate professionals, referenced appraiser(s) and/or peers, file information, and cost estimating resources. The scope of analysis may include reconsideration and reconciliation of value indications from the cost, sales comparison, and income approaches to value for the subject real property. Personal property values are excluded.

EXTRAORDINARY ASSUMPTIONS AND HYPOTHETICAL CONDITIONS: This review appraisal is based on the extraordinary assumption that the original appraisal report contained accurate location, condition and physical characteristic information on the subject property from an exterior and interior observation (if interior observation is applicable), and the comparable properties based on exterior observation. The review appraiser did not perform a physical observation of the exterior or the interior of the subject property, or any of the comparable sales in the original appraisal with the extraordinary assumption made that the information regarding these properties is accurate as of the date of the original appraisal. The use of extraordinary assumptions could significantly impact the conclusions and findings in the review appraisal if the information relied on for the extraordinary assumptions is found to be inaccurate.

HYPOTHETICAL CONDITIONS: Hypothetical conditions are contrary to what is known to exist but are asserted for the purpose of analysis. No hypothetical conditions were made as part of this appraisal review assignment.

## LIMITING CONDITIONS

## Certificate of Limiting Conditions:

1. The Review appraiser did not perform a physical inspection, interior or exterior, of the subject property or any of the comparable sales found in the appraisal under review or of the additional comparable sales provided to the Client.
2. The Review appraiser assumes no responsibility for the matters of a legal nature affecting the property which is the subject of this assignment or the title thereto, nor does the review appraiser render any opinion as to the title, which is assumed to be good and marketable.
3. The review appraiser assumes that there are no hidden or unapparent conditions of the property, subsoil, or structures, which would render it more or less valuable. The review appraiser assumes no responsibility for such conditions, or for the engineering which might be required to discover such factors.
4. Information, estimates, and opinions furnished to the review appraiser, and contained in the appraisal under review, were obtained from sources considered reliable and believed to be true and correct, unless stated elsewhere. If contradictory information is obtained and deemed reliable, and believed to be true and correct, the review appraiser will cite that source and the assumptions associated with that information. However, no responsibility for accuracy of such items furnished to the review appraiser can be assumed by the review appraiser.
5. Disclosure of the contents of the review report is governed by the USPAP and the Bylaws and Regulations of the professional appraisal organizations with which the review appraiser is affiliated.
6. No change of any item in the review report shall be made by anyone other the review appraiser and the review appraiser shall have no responsibility for any such unauthorized change.
7. The use of this review report is restricted to the client named within this report. Unless written consent is provided by the client and the review appraiser, use of this report by any other party is strictly prohibited.
8. The geographic competency to complete this limited scope review appraisal was acquired by the review appraiser's review and analysis of the original appraisal, the review and analysis of the supporting data that included both relevant area sales information, listing information and market information provided by additional recognized sources of real estate information.

# REVIEW APPRAISER'S SCOPE OF WORK, LIMITING CONDITIONS, AND CERTIFICATION (continued) 

## REVIEWERS CERTIFICATION

## I certify that, to the best of my knowledge and belief:

1. The statements of fact contained in this report are true and correct.
2. The reported analyses, opinions, and conclusions are limited only by the reported assumptions and limiting conditions and are my personal, impartial, and unbiased professional analyses, opinions, and conclusions.
3. I have performed no other services, as an appraiser or in any other capacity, regarding the property that is the subject of the work under review within the three-year period immediately preceding acceptance of this assignment.
4. I obtained the information, estimates, and opinions furnished by other parties and expressed in this review report from reliable sources that I believe to be true and correct.
5. I have not knowingly withheld any significant information from this report and, to the best of my knowledge, all statements and information in the report are true and correct.
6. I have no bias with the respect to the property that is the subject of this report or to the parties involved with this assignment.
7. My engagement in this assignment was not contingent upon developing or reporting predetermined results.
8. My engagement in this assignment was not contingent upon developing or reporting predetermined value or direction in value that favors the cause of the client, the amount of the value opinion, the attainment of a stipulated result, or of a subsequent event directly related to the intended use if this appraisal.
9. My analyses, opinions, and conclusions were developed, and this report has been prepared, in conformity with the Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP).
10. I have not made a personal inspection of the property that is the subject of this report.
11. I have not been provided with significant real property appraisal assistance. If there are exceptions, the name of each individual providing such assistance is stated below.

Borrower(s): Augustine M Lopez

## As required by California Law, you are hereby notified:

## NOTICE TO THE HOME LOAN APPLICANT

In connection with your application for a home loan, the lender must disclose to you the score that a credit bureau distributed to users and the lender used in connection with your home loan, and the key factors affecting your credit scores.

The credit score is a computer generated summary calculated at the time of the request and is based on information a credit bureau or lender has on file. The scores are based on data about your credit history and payment patterns. Credit scores are important because they are used to assist the lender in determining whether you will obtain a loan. They may also be used to determine what interest rate you may be offered on the mortgage. Credit scores can change over time, depending on your conduct, how your credit history and payment patterns change, and how credit scoring technologies change.

Because the score is based on information in your credit history, it is very important that you review the credit-related information that is being furnished to make sure it is accurate. Credit records may vary from one company to another.

If you have questions about your credit score or the credit information that is furnished to you, contact the credit bureau at the address and telephone number provided with this notice or contact the lender, if the lender developed or generated the credit score. The credit bureau plays no part in the decision to take any action on the loan application and is unable to provide you with the specific reasons for the decision on a loan application.

If you have questions concerning the terms of the loan, contact the lender.

## As required by Federal Law, you are hereby notified:

## NOTICE TO THE HOME LOAN APPLICANT

In connection with your application for a home loan, the lender must disclose to you the score that a consumer reporting agency distributed to users and the lender used in connection with your home loan, and the key factors affecting your credit scores.

The credit score is a computer generated summary calculated at the time of the request and is based on information a consumer reporting agency or lender has on file. The scores are based on data about your credit history and payment patterns. Credit scores are important because they are used to assist the lender in determining whether you will obtain a loan. They may also be used to determine what interest rate you may be offered on the mortgage. Credit scores can change over time, depending on your conduct, how your credit history and payment patterns change, and how credit scoring technologies change.

Because the score is based on information in your credit history, it is very important that you review the credit-related information that is being furnished to make sure it is accurate. Credit records may vary from one company to another.

# CHECKING YOUR CREDIT REPORT 

What if there are mistakes in your credit report?

How can you obtain a copy of your credit report?

You have a right to dispute any inaccurate information in your credit report. If you find mistakes on your credit report, contact the consumer reporting agency.

It is a good idea to check your credit report to make sure the information it contains is accurate.
Under federal law, you have the right to obtain a free copy of your credit report from each of the nationwide consumer reporting agencies once a year.

To order your free annual credit report--
By telephone: Call toll-free: 1-877-322-8228
On the web: Visit www.annualcreditreport.com
By mail: Mail your completed Annual Credit Report Request Form (which you can obtain from the Federal Trade Commission's web site at http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/conline/include/requestformfinal.pdf) to:

Annual Credit Report Request Service
P.O. Box 105281

Atlanta, GA 30348-5281
How can you get more information?

For more information about credit reports and your rights under federal law, visit the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's website at www.consumerfinance.gov/learnmore

CoreLogic Credco is a reseller of credit scores provided by the three national repositories, Equifax (EFX), Experian (XPN) and TransUnion (TUC). It is important to note that the information and credit scoring model (s) may be different than the credit scores (s) that may be used by the lender. The name, address, and website for contacting the person or entity who developed the score (s) or developed the methodology of the score (s) are as follows:

WHEN YOU PROVIDE A CHECK AS PAYMENT, YOU AUTHORIZE US EITHER TO USE INFORMATION FROM YOUR CHECK TO MAKE A ONE-TIME ELECTRONIC FUNDS TRANSFER FROM YOUR ACCOUNT OR TO PROCESS THE PAYMENT AS A CHECK TRANSACTION. WHEN WE USE INFORMATION FROM YOUR CHECK TO MAKE AN ELECTRONIC FUNDS TRANSFER, FUNDS MAY BE WITHDRAWN FROM YOUR ACCOUNT AS SOON AS THE SAME DAY WE RECEIVE YOUR PAYMENT AND YOU WILL NOT RECEIVE YOUR CHECK BACK FROM YOUR FINANCIAL INSTITUTION.

## UNDERSTANDING YOUR BILLING STATEMENT

Your monthly statement is mailed to you 10-20 days before your next payment due date.

## TOTAL AMOUNT(S) DUE

- The dollar amount showing in the 'Total Amount Due' field reflects the amount owed for the current month as well as any past due amounts.
- The 'Total Amount Due' may vary based on any previous payment amount received.
- Any payments credited to your account after your statement date will be reflected on your next monthly billing statement.
- If the 'Total Amount Due' indicates $\$ 0$, payments can still be made and applied to the account.
- 'Payoff Amt': This is the amount that must be received by the 'Good Thru' date to pay off your account. This amount differs from your account balance, which is the total of your remaining payments. (Applies to Retail Installment Contracts only)
- You may prepay the balance of your Retail Installment Contract, in whole or in part, at any time with no penalty.


## COMBINED ACCOUNT BILLING AVAILABILITY

- If you have two or more accounts and would like to receive a single billing statement allowing for one easy payment, please visit www.fordcredit.com or call our Customer Service Center.

PAYMENT METHODS - A WIDE VARIETY ARE AVAILABLE TO YOU

- Online - The fast, flexible and convenient way to schedule individual payments up to 30 days in advance or establish an automatic recurring monthly payment from your checking or savings account on our web site.
- Mobile - Take advantage of our online payment methods using your mobile device.
- Phone - Make payments via the telephone from a checking or savings account by calling 1-800-334-1161. Before using this service, you must read and agree to the service terms available on our web site or by calling customer service at 1-800-727-7000.
- Mail - Send payments by check using the envelope provided and the detachable part of your statement, 5 to 7 days before the due date. Please place your account number on your payment and make it payable to Ford Credit.
- Ford Credit also accepts payments made through

MoneyGram and Western Union. Receive same day credit on payments made on business days prior to 6 p.m. ET at MoneyGram or Western Union agent location. Fees will be charged by MoneyGram or Western Union. Visit www.fordcredit.com for full details on all available Payment Methods.

## QUESTIONS ABOUT YOUR BILLING STATEMENT?

Try our 24 hour automated phone system at 1-800-727-7000, which provides the following services:

- Last payment received and/or next payment due
- Amount due
- Payoff information and faxed quote (Applies to Retail Installment Contracts only)
- Information on an additional account
- Make payment arrangements for your account
- Order a duplicate statement

## MICROFILM

4. THE COURT ORDERS, GOOD CAUSE APPEARING:
a. $\square$ Judgment of dissolution is entered. Marital status is terminated and the parties are restored to the status of unmarried persons
(1) $\square$ on the following date (specify): May 20, 2005
(2) $\square$ on a date to be determined on noticed motion of either party or on stipulation.
b. $\square$ Judgment of legal separation is entered.
c. $\square$ Judgment of nullity is entered. The parties are declared to be unmarried persons on the ground of (specify):
d. $\square$ This judgment will be entered nunc pro tunc as of (date):
e. $\square$ Judgment on reserved issues.
f. $\square$ Wife's $\square$ Husband's former name is restored (specify):
g. $\square$ Jurisdiction is reserved over all other issues, and all present orders remain in effect except as provided below.
h. $\square$ This judgment contains provisions for child support or family support Both parties must complete and file with the court a Child Support Case Registry Form (form FL-191) within 10 days of the date of this judgment. The parents must notify the court of any change in the information submitted within 10 days of the change by filing an updated form. The form Notice of Rights and Responsibilities-Health Care Costs and Reimbursement Procedures and Information Sheet on Changing a Child Support Order (form FL-192) is attached.

MARRIAGE OF 1.0000
ACTION \#
ATTACHMENT 4 TO JUDGMENT
It is further ordered:

# CHILD CUSTODY AND VISITATION 

1. The parties shall share joint legal custody of the minor children, ${ }^{\text {Tory }}$ (born February 1, 1997, Susan (born May 2, 1998), and Frank (born December 26, 1999). Respondent shall have Physical Custody of the three minor children, and Petitioner shall have Reasonable Visitation with the three minor children. It is anticipated Respondent and the children will be moving to Michigan on or about December 16, 2004. Petitioner's visitation shall be as follows:
a) For the month of December 2004: (1) every weekend from Friday at 6 p.m. to Sunday at 6 p.m.; (2) weekday visits as requested by Petitioner, with a pickup after work and a return home no later than 9 p.m.; 3) if Petitioner travels to Michigan for Christmas, then Respondent shall have the children on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, and Petitioner will have the children on December 26 for Fran's birthday; (4) for the week of December 27, Petitioner shall have visitation as requested, with a return of the children to a home of Respondent's choosing by 9 p.m., unless the Parties agree otherwise.
b) Beginning January 2005 and continuing until the execution of a subsequent written agreement between the Parties or a Court order, while Petitioner resides in California and Respondent and the minor children reside in Michigan: (1) Petitioner shall have two weekends per month, beginning on Fridays at 6 p.m. with a return by 6 p.m. on the night before the next school day. The Parties have acknowledged that Petitioner may not be able to visit for two weekends in any given month. Petitioner shall provide Respondent with as much notice as possible regarding the weekends he would like visitation for, but at a minimum, Petitioner will provide seven (7) calendar days' notice to Respondent. Petitioner shall be responsible for all travel costs to Michigan for the visits, and for travel back and forth while in Michigan for the visits.
c) Beginning after Petitioner moves back to Michigan, and both Parties and the minor children all reside in Michigan, and remaining in effect until further written

agreement between the Parties or Court Order: (1) alternating weekends, beginning on Fridays at 6 p.m. to Sundays at 6 p.m.; (2) one weekday visit from 5:30 p.m. to a return no later than 8:30 p.m.; (3) floating and additional time as agreed and as permitted by the Parties' schedules, as agreed between the Parties
d) "Parenting Plan": Holidays and Breaks: (a) The Parties have acknowledged that Respondent had the entire Thanksgiving Week 2004 (through Friday November 26) as her Holiday Visitation and that she will have Christmas Eve and Christmas Day 2004, per her request. Beginning with New Years' Day on January 1, 2005, Respondent will have all the holiday visits through June 2005 while Petitioner resides in California. (b) In May 2005, prior to the end of the children's school year and the beginning of the 2005 summer break, the Parties will meet (telephonic is acceptable with facsimile transmissions) to develop a "Parenting Plan", which includes the children's school schedules for 2005-6, and the Holiday and Break visitation schedule for the remainder of 2005, including the 2005 summer break. The Parties understand and agree that Petitioner is entitled to two weeks of the 2005 summer break, which will be apportioned at the May 2005 meeting. If Petitioner wants the children to spend this break time in California with him, he will bear the costs of transporting the children and a chaperone (for the flight) to California.
e) No Child Support Penalties for Disproportionate Time Share: The Parties have acknowledged and agreed that Petitioner will not be penalized in the child support calculation if he is unable to fully exercise his visitation times as allotted above, prior to his move to Michigan, due to the unique circumstances of this move-away case. The Parties agree that the consideration for not penalizing Petitioner, if different time-share amounts actually occur, is Petitioner's agreement to let Respondent and the three (3) minor children move to Michigan immediately without Petitioner contesting the move, and the acknowledged costs and access difficulties Petitioner may experience as a result.
f) Custody and Visitation Effective through at least calendar year 2005: (a) This Custody and Visitation Order shall remain in effect until the execution of a subsequent written agreement between the Parties or a subsequent Court Order. However, the Parties shall meet in

October 2005 to review this Custody and Visitation Order, after both Parties have a better understanding of what occurs during the next twelve (12) months. (b) After the October 2005 Review, either Party may file a motion with a competent Court to modify this Custody and Visitation Order as if the Court were initially determining Custody and Visitation. (c) At the October 2005 Review, the Parties shall negotiate in good faith to develop and implement a Parenting Plan, including Visitation, Holidays and Break schedules. If the Parties are not able to finalize a Parenting Plan prior to January 1, 2006, for calendar year 2006, then the Parties will alternate Holidays and share equally breaks until a new Court Order is in place, with the Parties sharing equally the 2005 Christmas break and Petitioner having the latter week in the 2005 Christmas break, including December 31, 2005 and January 1, 2006. The Parties may apply to the Court for judicial intervention to finalize a Parenting Plan for 2006 and beyond.
g) Travel Outside of the United States of America: Neither Party shall travel with the minor children outside of the United States without the written consent of the other Party or Court Order. However, the Parties recognize that Respondent may want to take the three (3) minor children to Italy during the 2005 summer break. The Parties agree that Respondent may take the children to Italy for part of the 2005 summer break, so long as any trip to Italy does NOT interfere with Petitioner's two-week break time, and with the express understanding that the calculation of Petitioner's timeshare for support calculation purposes will not be adversely affected due to Respondent's exclusive time with the kids during the Italy trip. Any additional out of country trips will be addressed in the Parenting Plan or a separate written document executed by the Parties.
h) Weekly Contact: Respondent agrees to encourage and not frustrate weekly contact between Petitioner and the children while Petitioner is living in California and the children are living in Michigan. At a minimum, Petitioner and the children should speak at least once per week by telephone.
i) 80000 Educational Placement and Additional Educational Benefits: The Parties agree that Julia is a "special needs" child and that she has a legal disability as defined under Federal and California law. Susan requires annual Individual Education Plan ("IEP")

meetings with the local school district that require the parents, teachers, and therapists to evaluate
scour's progress and set target goals for the upcoming school year. The Parties agree to concur jointly in the selection of the educational placement and additional therapeutic isems for Susan If the Parties cannot agree, or if one Party makes unilateral decisions pursuant to this subsection, without conferring with the other Party, then either Party may file a motion with a Court of competent jurisdiction to set aside the other Party's unilateral decisions or to request judicial intervention. Any monies provided by the States of California or Michigan for the respite care or treatment of Julia may be retained by the parent with Physical Custody, or will be shared equally if both Parties eventually share Physical Custody.
2. The Parties have acknowledged and agreed as follows for purposes of compliance with California Family Code section 3048, subdivision (a):
3. Custody jurisdiction is Contra Costa County, California is based on the children's residence and both parents' residence in Contra Costa County. California is the home state of the children at the time of this Agreement.
4. Petitioner filed the Petition for Dissolution of Marriage on November 1, 2004, and Petitioner served Respondent on November 3, 2004, which is when the Court acquired jurisdiction over Respondent. Respondent filed her Response to the Petition on November 19, 2004. Both Parties have acknowledged and agreed that this matter may proceed as an uncontested matter, and waive notice of hearing or trial of any and all issues pertaining to Child Custody and Visitation.
5. The Custody and Visitation rights over the Parties' minor children are set forth in this Agreement, above.
6. Both Parties have acknowledged their awareness that a violation of the Custody and Visitation orders that will be issued based on this Agreement may subject that Party to civil and/or criminal penalties.
7. The Parties have agreed that the United States of America is the country of habitual residence of their minor children.

8. Move to Michigan: The parties anticipate that Respondent and the minor children will be moving to Michigan shortly and that Petitioner intends to relocate to Michigan in mid2005. Once both parties and the children are Michigan residents, the parties will cooperate to transfer jurisdiction over custody, visitation and child support issues to a court of competent jurisdiction in that state, consistent with the UCCJEA, the FPKPA and other applicable law.
9. Surname of the Minor Children. For the duration of their minority, the Parties' children Susan, Terry and Frank shall bear Petitioner's surname, Lome, on all legal documents, including birth certificates, insurance records, school records and any other legal documents, and shall not assume any other surname or Respondent's future married name (if any), or any other surname, unless the Parties agree in writing to modify this Agreement.

# CHILD SUPPORT 

10. Petitioner shall pay to Respondent for Child Support for the three (3) minor children Terry (born 2/1/1997), Susan (born 5/2/1998), and Frank (born 12/26/1999), the sum of $\$ 1,500$ per month, payable in equal one-half installments no later than the second and sixteenth days of each month, commencing on December 1, 2004, and continuing until written modification between the Parties or by Court order.
11. The foregoing child support is based on assumptions as set forth in paragraph 21 of the parties' MSA (attached hereto).
12. Miscellaneous Out-Of-Pocket Expenses and Health Insurance: The Parties have acknowledged and agreed that Petitioner shall continue to pay one-half (1/2) of the Parties' out-of-pocket expenses for the children's health insurance, dental insurance, and extracurricular activities. The Parties have agreed that they will work together to seek the most affordable health care, including options through employment, and if one Party can get health care for the children through employment, that Party will be required to do so, with the Parties then sharing equally out-of-pocket health and dental care costs for the children. However, since Petitioner currently pays Two Hundred Twenty-Nine Dollars (\$229) per month for the entire family for Kaiser Permanente Health Insurance, he will NOT be required to pay more than this amount over the next (12) Twelve months or until Petitioner obtains new employment in Michigan, whichever

first occurs. Petitioner will provide coverage for the children through any health insurance available in such new employment, after consultation with Respondent.
13. December 2005 Review: The Parties shall meet in December 2005 to review the Child Support Order, after the Custody and Visitation Order is also reviewed. The Parties shall utilize the Michigan Friend of the Court guideline support formula, as it exists on December 31, 2005, to be effective on January 1, 2006.
14. Maintaining Life Insurance: Petitioner shall maintain the Fortes Life Insurance policy, or other life insurance with a payout value of at least $\$ 350,000$ during the minority of the children, with not less than $\$ 175,000$ payable to Respondent, and not less than $\$ 175,000$ payable to the children in equal shares (one-third to each).
15. Family Code Section 4065 Compliance: The Parties have acknowledged that
(a) they are fully informed of their rights concerning Child Support; (b) the above Child Support provisions are being agreed to without coercion or duress; (c) this Agreement for Child Support is in the children's best interests; and (d) the children's needs will be adequately met by this Child Support arrangement.
16. The Parties further declare their rights to Child Support have not been assigned to the county pursuant to section 11477 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code, and no public assistance application is presently pending.
17. The Parties have acknowledged that Child Support of the minor children is always subject to modification by a Court of competent jurisdiction at any time during the children's minority, and that this paragraph or any later child support order is subject to modification.
18. As evidenced by Exhibit "D" to the MSA herein and based on the assumptions set forth in paragraph 21 thereof, the parties believe the Child Support provided herein approximates guideline support.

# SPOUSAL SUPPORT 

19. Pursuant to paragraph 27 of the parties' MSA, spousal support jurisdiction is terminated.

## IT IS SO ORDERED.

# MARITAL SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 

## MARRIAGE OF <br> 1. 

## CONTRA COSTA COUNTY SUPERIOR COURT CASE NUMBER D04-05383

THIS MARITAL SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT ("Agreement") is made and entered into on December 10, 2004, in Clayton, California, by and between Petitioner Augustine M
lopez (Augustine also referred to as "Husband"), and Respondent
(Argeta $\quad$ ', also referred to as "Wife"), referred to collectively as "The Parties." This Agreement is based upon the following facts and assertions:
A. The Parties were married on August 4, 1996, in Boca Raton, Florida, and have been residing together as Husband and Wife continuously since that date. The parties separated on October 10, 2004, constituting a Marriage of eight (8) years, two (2) months and six (6) days.
B. The Parties are the parents of three (3) minor children: ,Tarry Datta

| Lopez | ("Tarry | "), a girl born on February 1, 1997 in Dearborn, Michigan; | "Susan |
| :--: | :--: | :--: | :--: |
| Katrina | Lopez | ("Susan "), a girl born on May 2, 1998 in Dearborn, Michigan; and |  |
| Frank David | Lopez | ("Joseph"), a son born on December 26, 1999 in Walnut Creek, California. The Parties do not have any other minor children of the marriage and have not adopted any children. |  |

C. Irreconcilable differences have arisen between the parties that has lead to the irremediable breakdown of their marriage. The Parties agree that no further waiting period, marriage counseling, or conciliation efforts would save the marriage, and Husband filed for dissolution of their marriage on November 1, 2004. The Dissolution of Marriage proceeding is pending in the Contra Costa County Superior Court, Case No. with Husband the Petitioner and Wife the Respondent.
D. The Parties intend this Agreement to be a final and complete settlement of all of their rights and obligations as between them, including but not limited to the Parties' community

property rights and claims, the rights of either Husband or Wife to seek Spousal Support, the Custody and Visitation Agreements, and the rights of Husband and Wife to receive Child Support. Custody, Visitation and Child Support will always be subject to the continuing jurisdiction of a Court of competent jurisdiction to modify these Agreements for any and all of the un-emancipated minor children.
E. The Parties are presently both in good health, and neither has any known illness, disability or physical condition that renders either incapable of gainful employment or makes either subject to extraordinary medical or dental expenditures in the near future.

F Autortine is currently employed as an Associate Attorney with the LAW OFFICES OF in Fremont, California, presently earning $\$ 83,000$ per year, or $\$ 6,916$ per month.
G. Arguis is currently unemployed but previously worked part-time as an Event Manager / Bartender with in Alameda County, California, earning an average of about $\$ 1000$ per month over the last couple years, and also previously worked parttime for both the in Alameda County, California, and for the in Concord, California. Early in the marriage, while the Parties resided in Michigan, she worked for in Taylor, Michigan. Husband believes that Wife could work and earn at least $\$ 3000$ per month presently, while Wife disputes this contention, particularly under current circumstances, further contending that substantial additional child care costs would be incurred were she to return to work at this time.
H. The Parties acknowledge and agree that due to the unique circumstances of this move-away case, specifically that Argus has requested to move immediately to Michigan with the three minor children anc Auputine has agreed not to contest the move, that many uncertainties now exist regarding what will transpire in the next twelve (12) months regarding Visitation and Employment situations. The Parties have executed this Agreement to put some basic orders and agreements into place to provide some stability for the children due to their impending move to

Michigan. The Parties acknowledge and agree that the provisions of the Dissolution of this Marriage, particularly Custody, Visitation, Child and Spousal Support, could be different if Anguia and the children remained in California or if Augustine ras also moving to Michigan at this time.

THEREFORE, for good and valuable consideration, including without limitation the mutual promises, conditions, covenants and agreements set forth herein, and in light of Anguia's and the children's immediate move-away to Michigan in December 2004, the Parties agree as follows:

1. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Agreement is effective as of the date of its signing and execution as set forth on the first page of this Agreement, which is December 10, 2004. This Agreement will be referenced, attached and incorporated into the Judgment for Dissolution of this case, which the Parties expect to be entered shortly after this Agreement was signed.
2. INDEPENDENT COUNSEL Augustine acknowledges that he is an attorney licensed by the State of California to practice law and that he represented himself in all stages of the negotiation, preparation and drafting of this Agreement and in the Dissolution of this Marriage. He further acknowledges that he has been advised to retain independent counsel in connection with these proceedings, but has freely chosen not to do so. Anguia acknowledges that she retained the services of $\qquad$ , of San Ramon, California, to provide her legal assistance and consultation at all stages of the negotiation, preparation and signing of this Agreement. Both Parties further acknowledge that they have carefully read and reviewed this Agreement and that the Parties fully understand the contents and legal effect of this Agreement.
3. VOLUNTARY AND INFORMED CONSENT. The Parties acknowledge and agree that they enter into this Agreement voluntarily, free from duress, fraud, undue influence, coercion, or misrepresentation of any kind by either Party or any third person.
4. DIVISION OF REAL AND PERSONAL PROPERTY. The real and personal property itemized in Exhibits "A" and "B" which are attached to this Agreement and fully

incorporated herein by reference, are complete lists of all of the Real Property and Personal Property of the Parties. The lists include community as well as separate property of the Parties. The Parties intend to divide these assets as set forth in Exhibits "A" and "B." Augustine areby confirms to Angela as her sole and separate property all of the property set forth in Exhibit "A." Angela hereby confirms tc Augustine is his sole and separate property all of the property set forth in Exhibit "B." The Parties have made the confirmations set forth in this paragraph with the intent that such transfers constitute an equal and equitable division of their Community Property and/or Quasi-Community Property. Except as otherwise provided in this agreement, the Party awarded any asset will also be awarded any insurance on the asset, and will take the asset subject to any outstanding loan or encumbrance, and that Party will pay and hold the other Party harmless from any encumbrances and liens on the asset, unless concealed by the other Party, and any insurance premiums and property taxes on the asset.
5. FORTIS LIFE INSURANCE POLICY. There is only one (1) Life Insurance Policy that was taken out during the Marriage and that is considered a possible Community Property Asset. This Policy was issued by FORTIS in 1997 and insures Augustine's life. Angela is the current policyholder. Augustine will retain this policy as his sole and separate property. As soon as practicable after the Effective Date of this Agreement, but in no event later than January 31, 2005, Angela will execute the necessary documentation transferring the ownership of the Fortis policy tc Augustine as identified in Exhibit A. In the event tha Augustine dies prior to the transfer of the ownership of the policy tc Augustine the parties intend that one-half the proceeds of the Policy will be paid to and retained by Angela, to assist in supporting the minor children, and the other half shall be paid in trust for the children in equal one third ( $1 / 3$ ) amounts. Angela will carry out these provisions even if all proceeds are paid directly to her.

# 6. PARTIES' WARRANTIES REGARDING EMPLOYMENT RELATED 

RETIREMENT OR BENEFIT PLANS. Each Party warrants to the other that, to the best of his or her knowledge after checking with his or her employers, neither Party is a voluntary or involuntary participant or beneficiary in or with respect to any retirement or benefit plan through a current employer or any prior employment during marriage. If either Party becomes aware of

his or her eligibility for or participation in any benefit plan not disclosed in this Agreement that is based in any degree on service during the Marriage and before Separation, that Party will notify the other Party of the existence of that eligibility or participation and authorize the plan to provide to the other Party any information necessary to calculate any community property interest, treating that community property interest as an omitted asset subject to the continuing jurisdiction of the Court.

# 7. SALE OF FAMILY RESIDENCE: EQUALIZING PAYMENTS; NO 

EPSTEIN/WATTS CREDITS TO EITHER PARTY. Dina can immediately sell the former family home, located at $\mathcal{M}$ Golden Plage Clayton, Contra Costa County, California (the "Clayton home"), Title to which is held only in Angela 's name, and for which Angela has had exclusive use and possession since October 10, 2004. After the required Escrow/Closing costs are deducted from the sale of the home, the Escrow Company / Funds distributor will first issue a Cashier's Check to Augustine Lopez for Twenty-Six Thousand Dollars (\$26,000), which represents an equalizing payment for the apportionment of the Parties' community assets and debts. The remaining funds shall be deemed Angela 's sole and separate property and will be issued to Angela or a designee of her choosing.
8. WARRANTIES OF DISCLOSURES OF PROPERTY. Each Party warrants to the other Party that all property in which the community has or may have an interest in, and of which either Party has knowledge of, has been disclosed to the other Party and listed in this Agreement. Each Party further warrants that neither Party possesses any interest in any property not set forth in this Agreement, whether Community-, Quasi-Community-, tenancy in common or joint tenancy property, in which the community may have an interest.

The Parties acknowledge their understanding that they are subject to "fiduciary duties" as defined in California Family Code sections 721, 1100(e), 2100 and 2102, which include, but are not limited to, the obligation to make full disclosures of all material facts and information regarding the existence, characterization and valuation of all assets in which the community has or may have an interest, and debts for which the community is or may be liable, and to provide equal access to all information, records and books pertaining to the character and value of those

assets and debts, upon request. The Parties further acknowledge that each Party has conscientiously endeavored to fulfill the duties of disclosure imposed upon each of them by said Family Code sections and California law, with respect to this Agreement and this case.
9. WARRANTIES OF VALUES OF PROPERTY. The Parties have made the transfers of property set forth in Exhibits "A" and "B" based upon the items and estimated values as of December 1, 2004, with the intent that such apportionment and division constitutes an equitable division of their community property, as well as a confirmation of their separate property interests.

The Parties agree and understand that the values used by them in dividing the Community Property were approximate and not necessarily exact, but these values were intended to be reasonably accurate and are warranted to be the best estimates of such items and/or values. The Parties each acknowledge and agree that they have chosen to enter into this Agreement without benefit of formal discovery or further discovery or investigation, and without all of the documentation that could be available to confirm or establish asset and debt values used in their estimates and analysis. Each Party hereby waives the right to such further discovery or investigation, because of their mutual desire for a prompt and final resolution and their belief that the values used are approximately correct.
10. AFTER-DISCOVERED PROPERTY. The Parties agree that any property or property interests discovered after the Effective Date of this Agreement, which would have been characterized as either Community or Quasi-Community Property for this Agreement, shall be divided equally between them. In the event that either Party has willfully concealed any such after-discovered property, that Party shall be obligated to pay to the other Party one-half of the value of the property as of the effective date of this Agreement, plus interest thereon at the rate of ten percent ( $10 \%$ ) per annum until paid, or one-half the value of the property on the date of its discovery or actual division, whichever is greater, together with any damages including but not limited to costs of enforcement and attorney fees incurred in obtaining its recovery.

# 11. CONFIRMATION OF PERSONAL BELONGINGS. Certain items of personal 

or sentimental value, such as personal apparel and jeweiry, have already been divided between the Parties and are currently in their possession. The Parties agree that the distribution of these items was an equitable division of such property, and each confirms to the other Party all such property now in that Party's possession.
12. DIVISION OF DEBTS AND OBLIGATIONS. The Parties agree that the debts and obligations listed in Exhibit "C" which is attached to this Agreement and fully incorporated herein by reference, shall be paid as set forth in that exhibit, and that each Party will pay and hold the other harmless from the debts set forth opposite the name of each. Any debts and obligations that are not listed in Exhibit "C" are the sole and separate responsibility of the Party who incurred the debt or obligation, unless the debt or obligation is determined to be a community debt.

Each Party warrants to the other that since the Date of Separation, he/she has not incurred any debt or obligation for which the other or the community can be held liable, except as specifically set forth in Exhibit "C." The Parties acknowledge and agree that any debt or obligation incurred by either Party after the Date of Separation, October 10, 2004, shall be the sole and separate responsibility of that Party, and each Party agrees to hold the other Party harmless against any such debt or obligation, and each Party further agrees to indemnify the other Party against any liability incurred in connection therewith, including but not limited to court costs, attorney fees and all other costs of defense.

## 13. WAIVER OF RIGHTS IN THE PARTIES' RESPECTIVE ESTATES. <br> Aunition

and Anuria agree that effective immediately, regardless of whether the actual written changes are made in any separate document such as a Will or TRUST, that each Party waives and relinquishes, to the fullest extent lawfully possible, all rights, title, claims, liens, or interests in, whether actual, inchoate, present, future, vested or contingent, in law and in equity, under the laws of any state or under federal law, in the other's Separate Property, Separate Property income, and Separate Property estate by reason of their marriage, including, without limitation, the following:

(a) All Community Property, Community Property rights, Quasi-Community Property, and Quasi-Community Property rights;
(b) The right to a probate family allowance;
(c) The right to a probate homestead;
(d) The rights or claims of dower, curtsey, or any statutory substitute now or hereafter provided under the laws of any state in which the Parties may die while domiciled, or in which they may own real property;
(e) The right to inherit Separate Property from the other by intestate succession;
(f) The right to receive Separate Property that would pass from the decedent Party by testamentary disposition in a Will executed before this Agreement;
(g) The right of election to take against the Will of the other;
(h) The right to take the statutory share of an omitted spouse;
(I) The right to be appointed as administrator of the deceased Party's estate, or as executor of the deceased Party's will, unless appointed pursuant to a Will executed after the effective date of this Agreement;
(k) Any right created under federal law, including, without limitation, the Retirement Equity Act of 1984 and the Employee Retirement and Income Security Act (ERISA); and
(I) Any right, title, claim or interest in or to the Separate Property, Separate Property income or Separate Property estate of the other by reason of the Parties' Marriage.

# 14. JOINT LEGAL CUSTODY, PHYSICIAL CUSTODY TO DINA, OF THE 

MINOR CHILDREN DANIELLE, JULIA AND JOSEPH. The parties shall share Joint Legal Custody of the minor children Susan, Tarry and Frank

Angela shall have
Physical Custody of the three minor children, and Augustine shall have Reasonable Visitation with the three minor children. It is anticipated Angela and the children will be moving to Michigan on or

about December 16, 2004. Augustine visitation shall be as follows:
a) For the month of December 2004: (1) every weekend from Friday at 6 pm to Sunday at 6 pm ; (2) weekday visits as requested b) Augustine with a pickup after work and a retu.a home no later than 9 pm ; (3) if Augustine avels to Michigan for Christmas, then Angel will have the children on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day, and Augustine vill have the children on December 26 for Franks birthday; (4) for the week of December 27, Matt shall have visitation as requested, with a return of the children to a home of Angel's choosing by 9 pm , unless the Parties agree otherwise.
b) Beginning January 2005 and continuing until the execution of a subsequent written agreement between the Parties or a Court order, while Augustine resides in Califormia and Angelia and the minor children reside in Michigan: (1) Augustine vill have two weekends per month, beginning on Fridays at 6 pm with a return by 6 pm on the night before the next school day. The Parties acknowledge that Matt may not be able to visit for two weekends in any given month. Augustine will provide Angelia with as much notice as possible regarding the weekends he would like visitation for, but at a minimum, Augustine vill provide seven (7) calendar days' notice tc Angelia Augustine will be responsible for all travel costs to Michigan for the visits, and for travel back and forth while in Michigan for the visits;
c) Beginning after Matt moves back to Michigan, and both Parties and the minor children all reside in Michigan, and remaining in effect until further written agreement between the Parties or Court Order: (1) alternating weekends, beginning on Fridays at 6 pm to Sundays at 6 pm ; (2) one weekday visit from 5:30pm to a return no later than 8:30pm; (3) floating and additional time as agreed and as permitted by the Parties' schedules, as agreed between the Parties;
d) "Parenting Plan": Holidays and Breaks: (a) The Parties acknowledge that Aigela lad the entire Thanksgiving Week 2004 (through Friday November 26) as her Holiday Visitation and that she will have Christmas Eve and Christmas Day 2004, per her request. Beginning with New Years' Day on January 1, 2005 Aigela will have all the holiday visits through June 2005 while Augustine esides in California. (b) In May 2005, prior to the end of the children's school year and the beginning of the 2005 summer break, the Parties will

meet (telephonic is acceptable with facsimile transmissions) to develop a "Parenting Plan", which includes the children's school schedules for 2005-6, and the Holiday and Break visitation schedule for the remainder of 2005, including the 2005 summer break. The Parties understand and agree that Augustine s entitled to two weeks of the 2005 summer break, which will be apportioned at the May 2005 meeting. If Augustine vants the children to spend this break time in California with him, he will bear the costs of transporting the children and a chaperone (for the flights) to and from California.
e) No Child Support Penalties for Disproportionate Time Share: The Parties acknowledge and agree tha Augustine vill not be penalized in the child support calculation if he is unable to fully exercise his visitation times as allotted above, prior to his move to Michigan, due to the unique circumstances of this move-away case. The Parties agree that the consideration for not penalizing Augustine if different time-share amounts actually occur, it Augustine i agreement to let Angela und the three (3) minor children move to Michigan immediately withou Augustine contesting the move, and the acknowledged costs and access difficultie Augustine may experience as a result of the children's immediate move to Michigan.
f) Custody and Visitation Effective through at least calendar year 2005: (a) The Parties intend that this Custody and Visitation Order will remain in effect until the execution of a subsequent written agreement between the Parties or a subsequent Court Order. However, the Parties shall meet in October 2005 to review this Custody and Visitation Order, after both Parties have a better understanding of what occurs during the next twelve (12) months. (b) After the October 2005 Review, either Party may file a motion with a competent Court to modify this Custody and Visitation Order as if the Court were initially determining Custody and Visitation. (c) At the October 2005 Review, the Parties shall negotiate in good faith to develop and implement a Parenting Plan, including Visitation, Holidays and Break schedules. If the Parties are not able to finalize a Parenting Plan prior to January 1, 2006, for calendar year 2006, then the Parties will alternate Holidays and share equally breaks until a new Court Order is in place, with the Parties sharing equally the 2005 Christmas break anc Augustine saving the latter week in the 2005 Christmas break, including December 31, 2005 and January 1, 2006. The Parties

may apply to the Court for judicial intervention to finalize a Parenting Plan for 2006 and beyond.
g) Travel Outside of the United States of America: Neither Party shall travel with the minor children outside of the United States without the written consent of the other Party or Court Order. However, the Parties recognize that ${ }^{\text {Angst }}$ nay want to take the three (3) minor children to Italy during the 2005 summer break. The Parties agree that Angsta nay take the children to Italy for part of the 2005 summer break, so long as any trip to Italy does NOT interfere with Augustine i two-week break time, and with the express understanding that the calculation of Augustine timeshare for support calculation purposes will not be adversely affected due to Angstia i exclusive time with the kids during the Italy trip. Any additional out of country trips will be addressed in the Parenting Plan or a separate written document executed by the Parties.
h) Weekly Contact: Angsta agrees to encourage and not frustrate weekly contact between Augustine and the children whil Augustine is living in California and the children are living in Michigan. At a minimum, Matt and the children should speak at least once per week by telephone.
i) Susari Educational Placement and Additional Educational Benefits: The Parties agree that Susan is a "special needs" child and that she has a legal disability as defined under Federal and California law. Susan requires annual Individual Education Plan ("IEP") meetings with the local school district that require the parents, teachers, and therapists to evaluate Susari's progress and set target goals for the upcoming school year. The Parties agree to concur jointly in the selection of the educational placement and additional therapeutic items for Susan . If the Parties cannot agree, or if one Party makes unilateral decisions pursuant to this subsection, without conferring with the other Party, then either Party may file a motion with a Court of competent jurisdiction to set aside the other Party's unilateral decisions or to request judicial intervention. Any monies provided by the States of California or Michigan for the respite care or treatment of Julia may be retained by the parent with Physical Custody, or will be shared equally if both Parties eventually share Physical Custody.

# 15. NO ASSERTIONS BY EITHER PARTY REGARDING THE PROPER CUSTODY, VISITATION, CHILD SUPPORT ORDERS. The Parties acknowledge and 

understand that by making these agreements now, pursuant to Angelss request to immediately move with the minor children to Michigan, and prior to further discovery or judicial involvement, the Parties are NOT making any assertions or statements regarding what the proper Custodial, Visitation, or Child Support Agreements or Orders should be or would be if the Parties were to remain in California together or if the Parties were to move immediately to Michigan together. The Parties agree that these Agreements and Orders are being put into place now primarily because Angela as requested an immediate move to Michigan with the minor children. In the future, the Parties are free to file for a modification of Custody, Visitation and Child Support, and to ask a Court to determine Custody and Visitation as if the Court were making an initial determination of Custody and Visitation, with Child Support a derivative of those orders.

## 16. FAMILY CODE SECTION 3048 COMPLIANCE: The Parties further

acknowledge and agree as follows for purposes of compliance with California Family Code section 3048, subdivision (a):
(a) Custody jurisdiction is Contra Costa County, California, and is based on the children's residence and both parents' residence in Contra Costa County. California is the home state of the children at the time of this Agreement.
(b) Matt filed the Petition for Dissolution of Marriage on November 1, 2004, and Matt serves Angela on November 3, 2004, which is when the Court acquired jurisdiction over Angela Angela filed her Response to the Petition on November 19, 2004. Both Parties acknowledge and agree that this matter may proceed as an uncontested matter, and waive notice of hearing or trial of any and all issues pertaining to Child Custody and Visitation.
(c) The Custody and Visitation rights over the Parties' minor children are set forth in this Agreement, above.
(d) Both Parties acknowledge their awareness that a violation of the Custody and

Visitation Orders that will be issued based on this Agreement may subject that Party to civil and/or criminal penalties.
(e) The Parties agree that the United States of America is the country of habitual residence of their minor children.
17. MOVE TO MICHIGAN: The parties anticipate that Angan and the three (3) minor children will be moving to Michigan shortly and that Ausation ttends to relocate to Michigan in mid-2005. Once both Parties and the children are Michigan residents, the Parties will cooperate to transfer jurisdiction over Custody, Visitation and Child Support issues to a Court of competent jurisdiction in that state, consistent with the UCCJEA, the FPKPA and other applicable state and federal laws.
18. DEPENDENCY EXEMPTIONS AND INCOME TAX ISSUES. The Parties agree to file their Federal and California Income Taxes as "Married Filed Jointly" for calendar year 2004. They will share equally any refund and pay equally any amounts owed to the state or to the Internal Revenue Service attributed to their earnings through September 30, 2004 (the end of the month nearest the date of separation). Each will be solely responsible for income taxes (including self-employment tax or social security tax) due on or refunds derived from their respective incomes on or after October 1, 2004: They will rely on their joint accountant to apportion their respective tax liabilities and/or share of tax refunds, consistent herewith, for 2004. Both Parties will cooperate to timely file their tax return for 2004. Beginning with calendar year 2005, the Party with physical custody of the minor children will have the right to claim the dependency exemption for the minor children for income tax purposes. If at some point in the future the Parties share physical custody of the minor children, they will execute a separate written agreement defining their rights to claim the dependency exemptions.

Each Party agrees to timely execute any waivers, declarations and/or other documents required by federal or state law to effect the Parties' intent as stated in this section, and each Party agrees to indemnity and hold harmless the other Party for any losses incurred as a result of the other Party's accidental, negligent or willful failure to timely execute said waivers, declarations and/or other documents for any single tax year for so long as this Agreement

remains in effect.
19. SURNAME OF THE MINOR CHILDREN. For the duration of their minority, the Parties' three (3) children $\qquad$ shall bear ${ }^{\text {Augustine's }}$ surname, $\qquad$ and any other legal documents, and shall not assume any other surname or Angels future married name (if any), unless the Parties agree in writing to modify this Agreement.
20. CHILD SUPPORT. Augustine will pay to ${ }^{\text {Angels }}$, for Child Support for the three (3) minor children Terry (born 2/1/1997), Susan (born 5/2/1998), and Frank born 12/26/1999), the sum of $\$ 1.500$ per month, payable in equal one-half installments no later than the second and sixteenth days of each month, commencing on December 1, 2004, and continuing until written modification between the Parties or by Court order.
21. ASSUMPTIONS USED IN CALCULATING SUPPORT. The Parties made the following assumptions for purposes of the calculation of the foregoing Child Support, with the understanding that except as specifically provided herein, said assumptions would have no precedential effect on future Child Support proceedings, and are without prejudice to the rights of either Party to assert different facts.
(a) Parties' Employment: The next twelve (12) months contain many uncertainties for the Parties' employment situations, based on Angels' request to immediately move back to Michigan with the minor children and Augustine's eventual job search in Michigan. For this calculation, the Parties have agreed to use Augustine's current employment income of $\$ 6950$ per month as his income; and the compromise amount of $\$ 1500$ per month as Angels's income, based on their varying estimates ranging from zero to $\$ 3000 / \mathrm{mo}$. or more for her potential income. The Parties acknowledge that if Angels's income is actually higher or Augustine's income is actually lower for calendar year 2005, Child Support shall not be reduced prior to January 1, 2006;
(b) Time Share: The next twelve (12) months contain many uncertainties for the Parties'

time share with the minor children, based on Anguies move back to Michigan with the minor children and the great distance between California and Michigan, which could make travel costs high. The actual time-share percentages that will result between the minor children and the Parties are uncertain at this time. For the support calculation, the Parties used a time-share amount of approximately (20\%) twenty percent for Augustine and the children prior to Augustine's nove to Michigan.
(c) Matt's Travel Costs to Michigan for Visitation: The Parties acknowledge that Augustine will incur increased travel costs to Michigan for visitation while Augustine esides in California and Angola and the minor children live in Michigan. These increased costs were estimated at between three hundred dollars ( $\$ 300$ ) and one thousand dollars ( $\$ 1000$ ) per month, with the sum of $\$ 800 / \mathrm{mo}$. used in the Child Support calculation. The Parties acknowledge and agree tha Augustine's travel costs could be higher or lower, but are truly uncertain as of the Effective Date of this Agreement;
(d) Other Assumed Factors: Other assumed factors used in calculating the initial Child Support order are set forth in Exhibit "D," a DissoMaster calculation;
(e) Waiver of modification of the Assumptions through calendar year 2005: The Parties agree that they cannot modify these assumptions used to calculate Child Support prior to January 2006, as consideration for Anguies immediate move to Michigan with the minor children and Augustine's ugreement not to contest the move;
(f) Increase in Child Support If Matt Receives a raise in 2005: Notwithstanding the foregoing, if Augustine sceives a salary increase during calendar year 2005, Child Support shall be increased retroactive to the date of such increase in salary, using the new income and the other assumptions above, based on the California support guideline on the DissoMaster support calculation program.

# 22. CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS CONTINUE UNTIL FURTHER 

MODIFICATION: Except as provided above, the foregoing Child Support will continue until further modification by the Parties or a Court Order, but no modification of the assumptions is allowable prior to January 1, 2006. The Parties acknowledge and agree that this monthly amount could be higher or lower based on many variables, but due to the unique circumstances of this

move-away case, $\mathrm{A}_{\text {equat's }}$ request to move immediately, and the Parties' employment situations, the Parties agree that this amount is satisfactory for calendar year 2005;

# 23. MISCELLANEOUS OUT-OF-POCKET EXPENSES AND HEALTI' 

INSURANCE: The Parties acknowledge and agree that Matt will continue to pay one-half (1/2) of the Parties' out-of-pocket expenses for the children's health insurance, dental insurance, and extracurricular activities. The Parties agree that they will work together to seek the most affordable health care, including options through employment, and if one Party can get health care for the children through employment, that Party will be required to do so, with the Parties then sharing equally out-of-pocket health and dental care costs for the children. However, since Augustine currently pays Two Hundred Twenty-Nine Dollars (\$229) per month for the entire family for Kaiser Permanente Health Insurance, he will NOT be required to pay more than this amount over the next (12) Twelve months or unti Augustine obtains new employment in Michigan, whichever first occurs Augustine vill provide insurance coverage for the minor children through any health insurance available in such new employment in Michigan, after consultation witl Aiguita to implement the best insurance plan possible for the children.
24. DECEMBER 2005 REVIEW: The Parties agree to meet in December 2005 to review the Child Support Order, after the Custody and Visitation Order is also reviewed. The Parties will utilize the Michigan Friend of the Court guideline support formula, as it exists on December 31, 2005, to be effective on January 1, 2006.
25. MAINTAINING LIFE INSURANCE: Augustine shall maintain the Fortes Life Insurance policy, or other life insurance with a payout value of at least $\$ 350,000$ during the minority of the children, with not less than $\$ 175,000$ payable to Aiguita and not less than $\$ 175,000$ payable to the children in equal shares (one-third to each).
26. FAMILY CODE SECTION 4065 COMPLIANCE: The Parties acknowledge that (a) they are fully informed of their rights concerning Child Support; (b) the above Child Support provisions are being agreed to without coercion or duress; (c) this Agreement for Child Support

is in the children's best interests; and (d) the children's needs will be adequately met by this Child Support arrangement.

The Parties further declare their rights to Child Support have not been assigned to the county pursuant to section 11477 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code, and no public assistance application is presently pending.

The Parties further acknowledge that Child Support of the minor children is always subject to modification by a Court of competent jurisdiction at any time during the children's minority, and that this paragraph or any later Child Support Order is subject to modification.

As evidenced by Exhibit "D," and based on the assumptions set forth in paragraph 21, the parties believe the Child Support provided herein approximates guideline support.

# 27. NO SPOUSAL SUPPORT PAYABLE TO EITHER PARTY: TERMINATION OF JURISDICTION BY ANY COURT OVER SPOUSAL SUPPORT. 

The Parties acknowledge and agree th:Augustine took $\$ 8,000$ and Angela ook $\$ 23,000$ of Community Property money in October 2004. The Parties agree tha:Angela :an retain the $\$ 23,000$ she took for temporary Spousal Support and Attorney's Fees and Costs, without a right of reimbursement tc Augustine nd without Angela eeking any additional funds from:Augustine or temporary Spousal Support or Attorney's Fees and Costs.

Augustine and Angela nutually waive forever any claim for Spousal Support from the other Party. The Court shall have no jurisdiction to modify this Spousal Support provision or to award any Spousal Support to either Party, either now or in the future. The Parties agree that no Court in any State can modify this Spousal Support Order or award new Spousal Support to either Party, as of December 10, 2004, the Effective Date of this Agreement. This waiver is executed by both Parties with full disclosure of all the relevant facts to the other Party, is executed without duress by both Parties, and constitutes a full and final release of both Parties from paying Spousal Support to the other Party.
28. NO PENDENTE LITE ORDERS IN EXISTENCE. The Parties acknowledge and agree that there are no pendente lite orders in place now, nor have there ever been any pendente lite orders issued by the court in this dissolution action.

29. RECONCILIATION. If the Parties shall at any time reconcile after December 10, 2004, the Effective Date of this Agreement, then this Agreement, including all property transfers made or agreed to be made, shall remain in effect until modified or revoked by another written agreement signed by each Party and specifying the facts of (a) reconciliation and (b) modification of this Agreement.

# 30. INCORPORATION OF AGREEMENT INTO JUDICIAL ACTION. This 

Agreement shall be incorporated into and become a part of the Judgment of Dissolution currently pending in the Contra Costa County Superior Court, case number D04-05383, for the purposes of merging into the Dissolution of this Marriage and for any Court Orders requiring the Parties to perform the executory provisions of this Agreement, with the exception that any warranties contained in this Agreement shall survive its merger and be enforceable independently of the Judgment, by a breach of warranty action.

## 31. ENTRY OF JUDGMENT OF MARRIAGE DISSOLUTION. The Parties agree

that they will request the court to approve and enter a Judgment for an uncontested Dissolution of Marriage on December 10, 2004 at the currently scheduled Order to Show Cause Hearing, and that the marital status will be terminated effective May 20, 2005, the earliest available date under California law, pursuant to Dina's Response filed on November 19, 2005. Both Parties acknowledge that they will not be prejudiced by the entry of Judgment now or the termination of the marital status on May 20, 2005, for items such as health insurance and life insurance. Both Parties agree to timely file any additional documents requested by the Court to terminate the marital status on May 20, 2005. If either Party causes a delay in the termination of the marital status that adversely affects the other Party, than that Party shall indemnify the other Party for all losses or damages incurred by the other Party by reason of such delay, including any adverse tax liabilities. Pursuant to item \#17 above, Move to Michigan, once the Parties are restored to the status of single persons and all the other issues in this Dissolution have been resolved by agreement or Court Order, Matt will file a motion to transfer jurisdiction of this case to the State of Michigan.

32. ENTIRE AGREEMENT: MUTUAL RELEASES. The Parties intend this Agreement to be a final, full and complete settlement of all of their rights and obligations arising out of their Marriage. Except as otherwise provided in this Agreement, each i arty releases the other Party from any and all debts, obligations, and liabilities owing to the other, whether incurred before or after December 10, 2004, the Effective Date of this Agreement. Each Party expressly releases and discharges the other Party, individually and for that Party's heirs, assigns, representatives, executors and administrators, and releases any right to claim against the other Party for the estate of the other Party, or to claim any interest in the property of the other Party, except as provided in this Agreement, whether such claims are known or unknown. Each Party expressly waives the provisions of California Civil Code section 1542, which provides:
"A general release does not extend to claims which the creditor does not know or suspect to exist in his favor at the time of executing the release, which if known by him must have materially affected his settlement with the debtor."
33. PARTIES AND PERSONS BOUND. This Agreement shall bind the Parties to the Agreement, and their respective heirs, assigns, representatives, executors and administrators and any other successors in interest.
34. COSTS OF ENFORCEMENT. In the event that either Party shall be required to bring any action or proceeding in any Court of competent jurisdiction to enforce any of the provisions of this Agreement, or any Court order made after merger of any provision of this Agreement in the Dissolution Judgment, the prevailing Party (as defined by the Court) in such action or proceeding shall be entitled to recover all costs of such enforcement proceeding, including reasonable costs and attorneys' fees as set by the Court. No such liability shall accrue unless ten days' (10) prior notice of the claimed default has been given to the alleged defaulting Party, and such Party may cure the default within that ten-day (10) period without liability for the other party's costs or fees.

35. EXECUTION OF INSTRUMENTS. The Parties agree that each Party will promptly execute and deliver to the other Party, upon request, any legal instrument, document of title or other legal document that may be necessary or convenient to carry out the provisions of this Agreement, including but not limited to, the division of property or confirmation of property set forth in this Agreement and the attached Exhibits. In addition, each Party agrees to remove the other Party's name from any joint credit cards, revolving credit accounts, letters of credit, or any other credit instruments or accounts that could subject the other Party to legal liability for debts incurred by using said accounts or instruments.
36. EXECUTION FORMALITIES. The Parties specifically agree that forthwith upon their execution of this Agreement, their respective signatures shall be acknowledged by a notary public, in their presence. The Parties further acknowledge that the date which is set forth on the first page of this Agreement is the actual date on which they and each of them are signing this Agreement, which will be different from the notarized date of this Agreement. This Agreement, and the final Judgment of Dissolution into which this Agreement has been merged, may be recorded at any time, and from time to time by either party in any place or office authorized by law for the recording of documents affecting title to or ownership status of property, real or personal, specifically including, but not limited to, any county in which either party resided during the marriage or after a final judgment of dissolution, and any county in which either party owns or may own real or personal property.
37. APPLICABLE LAW. This Agreement is executed in the State of California and shall be subject to and interpreted under the laws of California, except that any later modification to the Custody, Visitation, or Child Support Orders and Agreements may be interpreted pursuant to a Court of competent jurisdiction of another state.

38. MODIFICATION, REVOCATION AND TERMINATION. This Agreement may be altered, amended, modified, revoked or terminated only by an instrument in writing expressly referring to this Agreement, executed and signed by both Matt and Dina. Each of the Parties waives the right to claim, contend or assert in the future that this Agreement was modified, canceled, superseded or changed by oral agreement, course of conduct or estoppel. Nothing herein is intended, however, to restrict the power of a court of competent jurisdiction to modify provisions relating to custody, visitation or support of minor children.
39. INVALIDITY: SEVERALABILITY. This Agreement has been jointly negotiated between the Parties and was prepared by Augustine nd shall not be construed against either Party. If any term, provision or condition of this Agreement is later held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, void or unenforceable, the remainder of the provisions shall remain in full force and effect and shall in no way be affected, impaired or invalidated.

IN WITNESS THEREOF, the parties have executed this Agreement on the date set forth on this first page of this Agreement, December 10, 2004.

Augustine Lopez

| Angela Lopez | Wife and Respondent |
